content: more towards the front of the head mine i folded in half and attached on the head over the eyes fig 46 pouch- this is more a method than an a pattern i ll share the number of stitches i used but you can easily make the pouch as big or tall as you like your beginning chain will determine its widest part while the number of row will determine how tall your pouch is i also use a simple tie method to pull the pouch closed you can add a cord lock for more security think adjustable pieces on drawstring hoods or face masks row 1 chain 45 turn = 45 sts i highly suggest laying the finished chain on the underside of the bug to ensure the size is as you want it fig 47 45 half_double_crochet turn = 45 sts row 2 45 half_double_crochet turn = 45 45 half_double_crochet turn = 45 sts repeat row 2 until desired height or until the longest distance edges touch fig 48 final row 45 double_crochet across = 45 sts leave tail long enough to sew along the side and the bottom to the underside of the bug 17 © emma scanga 2020 assembly continued pouch continued- fold in half with double_crochet edge at the top fig 49 sew along the side to create a circular piece fig 50 attach to the underside of your bug using the row 1 beginning chain with the last row of double_crochet at the top fig 51 through 53 for ties i chain the original amount i did for the pouch then add 10 to 15 more chains cut end and bind off i leave a short 4 inch tail so i can string it through the double crochets fig 54 you can create one tie and use a cord lock or i crocheted 2 ties and used them opposite of each other so i could pull both ties to cinch the pouch shut fig 55 through 57 brushing optional some bugs look fuzzy use a bristle brush or pet wire brush to create the fuzzy texture like i did with the bumblebee spots and dots optional - if you ve created any extra markings for your bug sew those on or as some amigurumi creators do- use double sided fusible webbing i m not familiar with this technique so i simply tack my pieces on instead of sewing completely down 18 © emma scanga 2020 congratulations you now have an not so creepy bug that can be placed on a wall a shelf or as a pouch to hold a cherished item whatever you do i d love to see it use the link below to find me on my website instagram twitch facebook and more follow the yarn … to connect with me don t forget to tag me or use #inkyfoxtheyarnbandit so i can see your creations thank you for purchasing a copy of resources and links this pattern this pattern is
